sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Scanlon)
articles.description: Gatsby Functions provide front-end developers a way to write and use server-side code without the hassle of maintaining a server. If making money from open-source is of interest to you and your site isn’t built using Gatsby, this approach may well be the answer you were looking for.
articles.title: Monetize Open-Source Software With Gatsby Functions And Stripe

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Elie Sloïm)
articles.description: Twenty years ago, Elie Sloïm chose to dedicate his professional life to web quality assurance. He started asking, ”What does quality mean for a web user?” Well, this article explains everything he has learned along the way.
articles.title: Web Quality Assurance: From User Requirements To Web Risk Management

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)
articles.description: Integrating a CRM with your business website has numerous benefits. In this article, Zara Cooper explains what these benefits are and why websites should be integrated with a CRM platform.
articles.title: Reasons To Build A CRM-Powered Website For Your Business

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Marcel Moreau)
articles.description: For years, pseudo-elements have faithfully helped front-end developers implement creative designs. While they still have an important place, we can now leave pseudo-elements behind in some scenarios, thanks to newer CSS properties.
articles.title: Reducing The Need For Pseudo-Elements

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Tracy Osborn)
articles.description: When designing for digital spaces, it’s natural to default to digital mockup tools, but doing so cuts out a world of possibilities. Analog drawing can unleash your imagination and allow you to focus on what’s most important at the start: the ideas.
articles.title: The Power Of Pen And Paper Sketching

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kirill Myshkin)
articles.description: There are way too many options in Web Animations API to pick them up that easily. Learning how timing works and how to control the playback of several animations at once makes for a solid foundation on which to base your projects on.
articles.title: Orchestrating Complexity With Web Animations API

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Frederick O’Brien)
articles.description: They say content is king, and they’re right. The web has unlocked untold possibilities for storytellers — provided the story is right, of course. Here are some of our favorite examples of editorial content thriving in the digital realm.
articles.title: Web Design Done Well: Excellent Editorial

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sam Poder)
articles.description: When paired with ISR and Next.js’ API routes, SWR can be used to create a responsive user experience. In this article, Sam Poder explains what SWR is, where to use it (and where not), and how to build a website by using Incremental Static Regeneration.
articles.title: Using SWR React Hooks With Next.js’ Incremental Static Regeneration (ISR)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Michelle Barker)
articles.description: In this article, we’ll walk through the process of taking a seemingly simple design for a text-and-media component and deciding how best to translate it into code, keeping in mind the needs of both users and content authors.
articles.title: Developer Decisions For Building Flexible Components

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Iris Lješnjanin)
articles.description: What’s the state of HTML Email, Vue.js and Next.js? What are new, smart interface design patterns we could use? Let’s figure it out. With our brand new online workshops on front-end & design. Now with **free workshops** for you to test the waters.
articles.title: New Smashing Online Workshops on Front-End & UX

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Patrick Brosset)
articles.description: Learn what’s new with developer tools in Firefox, Edge, Chrome and Safari. Discover new and powerful features that will help you be more comfortable and productive when testing and debugging across browsers.
articles.title: What’s New With DevTools: Cross-Browser Edition

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Robin Marx)
articles.description: After almost five years in development, the new HTTP/3 protocol is nearing its final form. Let’s take a close look at the challenges involved in deploying and testing HTTP/3, and how and if you should change your websites and resources as well.
articles.title: HTTP/3: Practical Deployment Options (Part 3)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Berwyn Powell)
articles.description: Websites, unfortunately, aren’t as environmentally friendly as we might like them to be. This article contains some thoughts and experiences from trying to clean them up.
articles.title: Reducing Carbon Emissions On The Web

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Louis Lazaris)
articles.description: Interactive coding tools to help you learn CSS, JavaScript, SQL, React, Vim, regular expressions and Jamstack.
articles.title: Interactive Learning Tools For Front-End Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Dirk Weber)
articles.description: What exactly is a displacement filter? In this article, Dirk Weber explains the SVG `feDisplacementMap` filter primitive with a good number of examples to demonstrate the concept of animated displacement maps.
articles.title: A Deep Dive Into The Wonderful World Of SVG Displacement Filtering

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Átila Fassina)
articles.description: By combining some React APIs, we can accurately manage “simple” states. With Next.js though, we can quickly find situations where we need to accommodate many other requirements. Let’s have a look at some patterns to accomplish all that.
articles.title: State Management In Next.js

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: New month, new wallpapers! In this post, you’ll find inspiring wallpaper designs for September 2021. They were created with love by artists and designers from across the globe and are available with and without a calendar. Enjoy!
articles.title: Stories Of September (2021 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: There are many CSS optimization techniques to tackle potential file size and performance issues. Let’s take a look at some of them. After all, if deploying the refactored codebase causes loading or performance issues, it will result in less traffic and revenue, which might leave the management and project managers dissatisfied.
articles.title: Refactoring CSS: Optimizing Size And Performance (Part 3)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ichoku Chinonso)
articles.description: Compound components help developers build more expressive and flexible APIs to share state and logic within components. This tutorial explains how this can be achieved with the help of using the Context API and React to build components by using this advanced pattern.
articles.title: Compound Components In React

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Robin Berjon)
articles.description: The Web is still wrestling with issues we take for granted offline, privacy chief among them. These are steps The New York Times took to protect users’ data, and how you can too.
articles.title: Pushing Back Against Privacy Infringement On The Web

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: In this article, Leonardo explains how to use a "multi-monorepo" approach for making the development experience faster, yet keeping your PHP packages private. This solution can be especially beneficial for PRO plugin creators.
articles.title: Creating A Public/Private Multi-Monorepo For PHP Projects

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Portia Burton)
articles.description: In this article, you’ll learn how to save hours of tedious work of writing, updating, and correcting technical documentation. In this article, you will learn how to automate your documentation workflow with Vale and GitHub Actions.
articles.title: How To Automate Documentation Workflow For Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Robin Marx)
articles.description: After almost five years in development, the new HTTP/3 protocol is nearing its final form. Let’s take a close look at the performance improvements of HTTP/3, congestion control, head-of-line-blocking, and 0-RTT connection set-up.
articles.title: HTTP/3: Performance Improvements (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Mike Neumegen)
articles.description: The story of Jamstack CMSs goes all the way back to the 90s. In this article, we take a trip down memory lane to see how we got to the modern Jamstack CMSs we have today, and where they’re heading in the next decade.
articles.title: Jamstack CMS: The Past, The Present and The Future

articles.description: You might have heard of a CSV file but what does it mean?  In this article, we are going to learn what a CSV file is, and how to open and export them using Microsoft Excel and Google Sheets.  What is a CSV file? CSV stands for Comma Separated Values.
articles.title: CSV Format – How to Open a .csv File and Export it

articles.description: Freelancing can be an incredibly rewarding way to make money online. But it can also be quite difficult if you don't approach it in the right way.  It takes more than a stable internet connection to make a living as a freelancer. In order to make the big bucks, you’
articles.title: How to Start Freelancing – Tips for Launching a Successful Freelance Career

articles.description: In Web Development, REST APIs play an important role in ensuring smooth communication between the client and the server.  You can think of the client as the front end and the server as the back end.  Communication between the client (frontend) and the server (backend) isn't usually super direct. So
articles.title: REST API Best Practices – REST Endpoint Design Examples

articles.description: I've lately been noticing a pattern in React applications: developers protect certain routes on a web app from unauthorized users. articles.title: Dynamic Navigation in Next.js – How to Render Nav-Items Dynamically in a Next App

articles.description: Modern web applications usually perform more than one function. They often have more than one section, offer more than one service, and have a couple of clients. articles.title: Laravel Subdomains – How to Create and Manage Subdomains in Your Apps

articles.description: I'm excited to share freeCodeCamp's first official VS Code extension – a dark mode theme. This night mode theme is minimalistic, easy on the eyes, and will help you reach a coding flow state.  Here's a preview of
articles.title: VS Code Dark Theme – A freeCodeCamp Night Mode Style for Visual Studio Code

articles.description: You can now learn Relational Database concepts and SQL right inside your VSCode editor. This tutorial will walk you through how to install it using Docker.  During this full-length 300-hour course, you will learn to build more than a dozen projects. Some of them will involve step-by-step instructions, and others
articles.title: Relational Database Course – How to Learn SQL in VSCode Using Docker and freeCodeCamp

articles.description: Gatsby is a website generator. It is a free and open source framework based on React that helps developers build fast websites and apps. We just published a 9-hour Gatsby course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel that will teach you how to use the newest version of the framework.
articles.title: Learn Gatsby, a Static Site Generator

articles.description: Data science models are all around you. They could impact your admission to a school, whether you get hired (or fired), your work schedule, whom you date, whether you get a loan, what ads are shown to you, what social media posts you see, and so on. I have created
articles.title: Data Science Ethics – What Could Go Wrong and How to Avoid It

articles.description: Notepad is a built-in text editor that comes pre-installed on Windows machines of all versions – XP, Windows 7, Windows 8, Windows 10, and so on.  It is the default Windows text editor. You can think of Notepad as your VS Code or favorite text editor with fewer capabilities.  Coding with
articles.title: HTML File Text Editor – How to Open Web Page Code in Windows Notepad
